Fiction Genres.quote: Fantasy: 'The world is shaped by two things—stories we tell and the stories we believe.' (Patrick Rothfuss, *The Name of the Wind*).

Non-Fiction Categories.quote: Memoir: 'We tell ourselves stories in order to live.' (Joan Didion, *The White Album*).

Literary Theory.quote: Show, don’t tell: 'Don’t tell me the moon is shining; show me the glint of light on broken glass.' (Anton Chekhov).

Classic Literature.quote: Tragedy: 'Nothing is so common as the wish to be remarkable.' (Shakespeare, *Othello*).

Modernism.quote: Stream of consciousness: 'The past is hidden somewhere outside the realm, beyond the reach of intellect.' (Marcel Proust, *In Search of Lost Time*).

Poetry Fundamentals.quote: Meter & metaphor: 'Hope is the thing with feathers / That perches in the soul.' (Emily Dickinson).

Science Fiction.quote: Speculative futures: 'The door dilated.' (Frank Herbert, *Dune* — efficiency in worldbuilding).

Mystery & Thriller.quote: Red herrings: 'The key to good suspense is delay.' (Alfred Hitchcock).

Historical Fiction.quote: Verisimilitude: 'History is a set of lies agreed upon.' (Napoleon, adapted in *Wolf Hall*).

Philosophical Works.quote: Existentialism: 'Man is condemned to be free.' (Jean-Paul Sartre, *Being and Nothingness*).

Children’s Literature.quote: Moral allegory: 'Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It’s not.' (Dr. Seuss, *The Lorax*).

Graphic Novels.quote: Visual storytelling: 'A picture is worth a thousand words, but a comic is worth a thousand pictures.' (Art Spiegelman, *Maus*).

Epic Poetry.quote: Hero’s journey: 'Sing, O Muse, of the rage of Achilles.' (Homer, *The Iliad*).

Satire.quote: Irony as critique: 'It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.' (Jane Austen, *Pride and Prejudice*).

Dystopian Fiction.quote: Cautionary tales: 'Big Brother is watching you.' (George Orwell, *1984*).

Magical Realism.quote: Blurring reality: 'Many years later, as he faced the firing squad, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was to remember that distant afternoon when his father took him to discover ice.' (Gabriel García Márquez, *One Hundred Years of Solitude*).

Bildungsroman.quote: Coming of age: 'So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.' (F. Scott Fitzgerald, *The Great Gatsby*).

Postcolonial Literature.quote: Reclaiming voice: 'The empire writes back.' (Salman Rushdie, *Midnight’s Children*).

Pulp Fiction.quote: Genre appeal: 'The cheaper the crook, the gaudier the patter.' (Dashiell Hammett, *The Maltese Falcon*).

Experimental Writing.quote: Breaking form: 'No rules, no limits, no gravity.' (Mark Z. Danielewski, *House of Leaves*).

Literary Movements.quote: Romanticism: 'Poetry is the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings.' (William Wordsworth).

Authorial Voice.quote: Style: 'The difference between the right word and the almost right word is the difference between lightning and a lightning bug.' (Mark Twain).

Reader Response.quote: Death of the author: 'A text’s unity lies not in its origin but in its destination.' (Roland Barthes).

Cultural Impact.quote: Canon formation: 'Great books are those which everyone wishes they had read, but no one wants to read.' (Mark Twain).

Ethics in Storytelling.quote: Representation: 'Stories can break the dignity of a people, but stories can also repair that broken dignity.' (Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie).

Publishing Evolution.quote: From scrolls to e-books: 'The invention of the printing press was the Big Bang of the knowledge universe.' (Carl Sagan).

Future of Books.quote: AI co-creation: 'The next chapter will be written by humans and machines.' (GPT-4, edited by a human).
